query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 La bocca sollevò dal fiero pasto 2 quel peccator, forbendola a’ capelli 3 del capo ch’elli avea di retro guasto.
query.result:
**English:**
1 The sinner lifted his mouth from the fierce meal, 2 wiping it on the hair 3 of the head that he had mangled at the back.
**Cornish:**
1 An ben a dhrehevis ow syns a'n fyer pask, 2 an pechor, ow forbya henna dhe'n blew 3 a'n ben a vea owth a-dhia ow kolla.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
4 Poi cominciò: «Tu vuo’ ch’io rinovelli 5 disperato dolor che ’l cor mi preme 6 già pur pensando, pria ch’io ne favelli.
query.result:
**English:**
4 Then he began: "You want me to renew 5 the desperate sorrow that weighs on my heart, 6 even just thinking about it, before I speak of it.
**Cornish:**
4 Wosa henna a gommansis: "Thus ow a vynna 5 owth ow wra'th ow nowyth an dolor desperat 6 a wra'th owth ow golon, kyns owth ow kovsow."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
7 Ma se le mie parole esser dien seme 8 che frutti infamia al traditor ch’i’ rodo, 9 parlar e lagrimar vedrai insieme.
query.result:
**English:**
7 But if my words are to be seeds 8 that bear infamy for the traitor that I gnaw, 9 you will see me speak and weep at the same time.
**Cornish:**
7 Mes mar owth ow gerow a vydh hadow 8 a wra'th frooth infami dhe'n traytour owth ow rodo, 9 kovsow ha gweli owth ow welo yn keth termyn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
10 Io non so chi tu se’ né per che modo 11 venuto se’ qua giù; ma fiorentino 12 mi sembri veramente quand’ io t’odo.
query.result:
**English:**
10 I do not know who you are or by what means 11 you have come down here; but you truly 12 seem Florentine to me when I listen to you.
**Cornish:**
10 Nyns owth ow kovsow piv thus ow, nag drefen 11 owth thus ow dos owma; mes florentinek 12 owth owth ow semla dhe'm yn gwir pan owth ow klev.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
13 Tu dei saper ch’i’ fui conte Ugolino, 14 e questi è l’arcivescovo Ruggieri: 15 or ti dirò perché i son tal vicino.
query.result:
**English:**
13 You must know that I was Count Ugolino, 14 and this is Archbishop Ruggieri: 15 now I will tell you why I am such a neighbor to him.**Cornish:**
13 Ty dheus gwos ow kov Ugolino, 14 ha henna yw an arghanskoeb Ruggieri: 15 wosa henna dheudhis dhys ow kov kyns keffrys dha.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
22 Breve pertugio dentro da la Muda, 23 la qual per me ha ’l titol de la fame, 24 e che conviene ancor ch’altrui si chiuda,
25 m’avea mostrato per lo suo forame 26 più lune già, quand’ io feci ’l mal sonno 27 che del futuro mi squarciò ’l velame.
query.result:
**English:**
22 A small opening inside the Muda, 23 which for me has the title of hunger, 24 and which is also necessary for others to be shut in,
25 had shown me through its hole 26 many moons ago, when I had the bad dream 27 that tore the veil of the future for me.**Cornish:**
22 Pol ow tyller y’n mes an Muda, 23 henna a wra an hanow Glaw, 24 ha henna yw mes dhe byttegy dhe dus ow tos ynni,
25 a wra ow tos ow toskwedhes dre y toll, 26 lies moonys a-rag, pan wrug y droem drog, 27 a rynn an gweliow a-rag dhym.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Questi pareva a me maestro e donno, 29 cacciando il lupo e ’ lupicini al monte 30 per che i Pisan veder Lucca non ponno.
query.result:
**English:**
28 This one seemed to me a master and lord, 29 hunting the wolf and the wolf cubs on the mountain 30 so that the Pisans cannot see Lucca.
**Cornish:**
28 Heman na wra veu mester ha gonys, 29 ow chasya an bleidhow ha’n vleinhow war an menydh 30 rag an Byson gwelos Lugh a alla.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 Con cagne magre, studïose e conte 32 Gualandi con Sismondi e con Lanfranchi 33 s’avea messi dinanzi da la fronte.
query.result:
**English:**
31 With lean, studious, and thoughtful dogs, 32 Gualandi with Sismondi and Lanfranchi 33 had placed themselves in front.
**Cornish:**
31 Gansoghas magor, studyos ha konta 32 Gualandi gans Sismondi ha Lanfranchi 33 ow tosowghens ow boneth ow tal.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 In picciol corso mi parieno stanchi 35 lo padre e ’ figli, e con l’agute scane 36 mi parea lor veder fender li fianchi.
query.result:
**English:**
34 In a short course, the father and sons seemed to me weary, 35 and with their sharp claws, 36 I seemed to see them tearing their flanks.
**Cornish:**
34 Yn kours byghan, an tas ha’n mebyon a via fethys, 35 ha gans aga skannow golgh, 36 yth wravia ow tosowghens ow fetha aga flanken.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Quando fui desto innanzi la dimane, 38 pianger senti’ fra ’l sonno i miei figliuoli 39 ch’eran con meco, e dimandar del pane.
query.result:
**English:**
37 When I was awakened before dawn, 38 I heard my sons weeping in their sleep, 39 who were with me, and asking for bread.
**Cornish:**
37 Panns oen oen ow tosowghens kyns an jydh, 38 ow klevos ow tosowghens ow weli yn aga kosk, 39 oedha gansow, ow hwithra bara.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
40 Ben se’ crudel, se tu già non ti duoli 41 pensando ciò che ’l mio cor s’annunziava; 42 e se non piangi, di che pianger suoli?
43 Già eran desti, e l’ora s’appressava 44 che ’l cibo ne solëa essere addotto, 45 e per suo sogno ciascun dubitava;
46 e io senti’ chiavar l’uscio di sotto 47 a l’orribile torre; ond’ io guardai 48 nel viso a’ mie’ figliuoi sanza far motto.
query.result:
**English:**
40 You are indeed cruel, if you do not grieve 41 thinking of what my heart was foretelling; 42 and if you do not weep, at what are you accustomed to weeping?
43 Already it was morning, and the hour was approaching 44 when food used to be brought to us, 45 and because of his dream, each one was apprehensive;
46 and I heard the door below being locked 47 of the horrible tower; whereupon I looked 48 in the faces of my sons without saying a word.
**Cornish:**
40 Crud yw dha, mar nyns yw dha galar 41 ow tosowghens an pyth colon ow tosowghens; 42 ha mar nyns yw dha gwela, a pyth yw dha arvosowgh?
43 Oedha dedhens, ha’n our a via ow tosowghens 44 panns an boes oedha gansow bos, 45 ha dre hembronk pub onan a via ow tosowghens;
46 Ha’m klevos ow tosowghens ow tosowghens an dhor 47 a’n tolsowgh orth, ow tosowghens ow tosowghens 48 yn fasowgh ow tosowghens ow mebyon heb leverel ger.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
49 Io non piangëa, sì dentro impetrai: 50 piangevan elli; e Anselmuccio mio 51 disse: “Tu guardi sì, padre! che hai?”.
query.result:
**English:**
49 I did not weep, so deeply was I moved: 50 they wept; and my little Anselm 51 said: “What are you looking at so intently, father? What is the matter with you?”.
**Cornish:**
49 Nyns oen kevyas, kemmys oen dallethas: 50 ev oen kevyas; ha'gas Anselmuccio vy 51 a leveris: “Py lemyn, tas, pyth yw?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Perciò non lagrimai né rispuos’ io 53 tutto quel giorno né la notte appresso, 54 infin che l’altro sol nel mondo uscìo.
query.result:
**English:**
52 Therefore I did not weep nor did I answer 53 all that day nor the following night, 54 until the next sun rose in the world.
**Cornish:**
52 Rag henna nyns oen kevyas na’th yth leveris 53 oll an jorna na’th an nos wosa, 54 bys dhe’th nessa howl a dheuth dhe’n bys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
55 Come un poco di raggio si fu messo 56 nel doloroso carcere, e io scorsi 57 per quattro visi il mio aspetto stesso,
58 ambo le man per lo dolor mi morsi; 59 ed ei, pensando ch’io ’l fessi per voglia 60 di manicar, di sùbito levorsi
61 e disser: “Padre, assai ci fia men doglia 62 se tu mangi di noi: tu ne vestisti 63 queste misere carni, e tu le spoglia”.
query.result:
**English:**
55 As soon as a little ray of light 56 had entered the sorrowful prison, and I saw 57 my own reflection in four faces,
58 I bit both my hands in grief; 59 and they, thinking that I did it out of a desire 60 to eat them, suddenly rose up
61 and said: “Father, it will be much less painful for us 62 if you eat us: you clothed us 63 with this wretched flesh, and you strip it from us”.
**Cornish:**
55 Pan voa dhe’th golow a veu posyes 56 yn karghar ankow, ha my a welas 57 ow holgow vy yn peswar enep,
58 yth kavas vy ow dew dhew rag ankow; 59 ha ev, ow tos ow treylya owth fensa 60 rag hys a dhesi, a sevas dhe’n bys
61 ha leveris: “Tas, moy a vydh le a ni 62 mar teth kevi a ni: ty a’n gwiskas 63 an kigow truan ma, ha ty a’n spoyl”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
64 Queta’mi allor per non farli più tristi; 65 lo dì e l’altro stemmo tutti muti; 66 ahi dura terra, perché non t’apristi?
67 Poscia che fummo al quarto dì venuti, 68 Gaddo mi si gittò disteso a’ piedi, 69 dicendo: “Padre mio, ché non m’aiuti?”.
query.result:
**English:**
64 I was silent then, so as not to make them sadder; 65 we remained silent all day and the next; 66 ah, cruel earth, why did you not open up?
67 After we had reached the fourth day, 68 Gaddo threw himself down at my feet, 69 saying: “Father, why don’t you help me?”.
**Cornish:**
64 Yth tawas vy dhe’n bys rag na’n gwrians trist; 65 an jorna ha’n nessa ni a veu mudh; 66 ah, tir kalet, rag henna nyns oet tosyes?
67 Wosa henna pan veu ni dhe’n peswara jorna, 68 Gaddo a dheuth dhe’m gwaya dhe’m tramor, 69 ow leverel: “Tas vy, rag henna nyns owth skoedhya?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
70 Quivi morì; e come tu mi vedi, 71 vid’ io cascar li tre ad uno ad uno 72 tra ’l quinto dì e ’l sesto; ond’ io mi diedi,
73 già cieco, a brancolar sovra ciascuno, 74 e due dì li chiamai, poi che fur morti.
query.result:
**English:**
70 There he died; and as you see me now, 71 I saw the other three fall one by one 72 between the fifth and sixth day; whereupon I gave myself,
73 already blind, to groping over each of them, 74 and for two days I called to them, after they were dead.
**Cornish:**
70 Eno henna ev a verwis; ha kepar ha’m gweles vy, 71 my a welas an tri dhe gwaya unn ha unn 72 ynter an pympa ha’n wheksa jorna; rag henna my a roos,
73 ow tos dall, dhe brankal warbarth unn, 74 ha dhew jorna yth leveris dhe’n wosa henna ev oen marow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
75 Poscia, più che ’l dolor, poté ’l digiuno».
76 Quand’ ebbe detto ciò, con li occhi torti 77 riprese ’l teschio misero co’ denti, 78 che furo a l’osso, come d’un can, forti.
query.result:
**English:**
75 Then, more than grief, hunger overcame me».
76 When he had said this, with twisted eyes 77 he seized the wretched skull with his teeth, 78 which were as strong as a dog’s, against the bone.
**Cornish:**
75 Wosa henna, moy es an angow, an degi a veu moy.
76 Pan veu ev leverel henna, gans an dhewlagow kamm, 77 ev a gemeras an kavan truan gans y dhe’n, 78 oen kresek avel mar ki, dhe’n askorn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Ahi Pisa, vituperio de le genti 80 del bel paese là dove ’l sì suona, 81 poi che i vicini a te punir son lenti,
82 muovasi la Capraia e la Gorgona, 83 e faccian siepe ad Arno in su la foce, 84 sì ch’elli annieghi in te ogne persona!
85 Che se ’l conte Ugolino aveva voce 86 d’aver tradita te de le castella, 87 non dovei tu i figliuoi porre a tal croce.
query.result:
**English:**
79 Ah Pisa, disgrace of the peoples 80 of the fair land where the “sì” is spoken, 81 since your neighbors are slow to punish you,
82 may Capraia and Gorgona move, 83 and form a barrier for the Arno at its mouth, 84 so that it may drown every person in you!
85 For if Count Ugolino was rumored 86 to have betrayed you of your castles, 87 you should not have subjected his children to such a torment.
**Cornish:**
79 Ah Pisa, mesprysi an bobel, 80 a’n wlas teg le mayth an “sì” a leverir, 81 pan veu dha vesyon dhe’th kosha,
82 mos Capraia ha Gorgona, 83 ha gwruthyl seth dhe’n Arno warbarth y dowr, 84 rag henna yth fetha pub den ynnos!
85 Rag mar an Kont Ugolino a veu leverys 86 dhe vos treysys a’th kastel, 87 nyns esa dhe’th dhesi dhe vosya y vabow dhe’n kroes ma.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Innocenti facea l’età novella, 89 novella Tebe, Uguiccione e ’l Brigata 90 e li altri due che ’l canto suso appella.
query.result:
**English:**
88 Their tender age made them innocent, 89 new Thebes, Uguiccione and Brigata 90 and the other two whom the above canto names.
**Cornish:**
88 An oos nowydh a wrug ev innosek, 89 Nowydh Thebai, Uguiccione ha’n Brigata 90 ha’n nessa dhew o’th lever an kan a-ves.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
91 Noi passammo oltre, là ’ve la gelata 92 ruvidamente un’altra gente fascia, 93 non volta in giù, ma tutta riversata.
query.result:
**English:**
91 We passed beyond, where the frost 92 harshly binds another people, 93 not turned face down, but completely supine.
**Cornish:**
91 Ni a drehedhmos dhesempys, le mayth an eryr 92 yn kalessa yn feth pobel aral, 93 nag eus ow tos yn-nans, mes oll ow tos ow kul.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 E avvegna che, sì come d’un callo, 101 per la freddura ciascun sentimento 102 cessato avesse del mio viso stallo,
103 già mi parea sentire alquanto vento; 104 per ch’io: «Maestro mio, questo chi move? 105 non è qua giù ogne vapore spento?».
query.result:
**English:**
100 And although, as from a callus, 101 because of the cold every sensation 102 had ceased in the seat of my face,
103 already it seemed to me that I felt a little wind; 104 so I said: “My Master, what moves this? 105 Isn’t every vapor down here extinguished?”.
**Cornish:**
100 Ha byttegyns, kepar a gallos, 101 dre'n eryr pub sens o pewas skonchyas 102 ow sedhas ow fas yn-nans ow holan,
103 ow tos ow tevi nebes gwyns; 104 rag henna: “O'm Mester, pyw a wra dhe huni? 105 Nag eus pub vapor ow tos ow skonchyas?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Ond’ elli a me: «Avaccio sarai dove 107 di ciò ti farà l’occhio la risposta, 108 veggendo la cagion che ’l fiato piove».
query.result:
**English:**
106 And he to me: “Soon you will be where 107 your eyes will give you the answer to that, 108 seeing the cause that makes the wind blow”.
**Cornish:**
106 Ha henna dhe'm: “Yn skon a vydhi le mayth 107 le mayth dhe wul dhe hwel an golwg dhiso, 108 ow tos ow weles an acheson a wra'n gwyns ow kodha”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 E un de’ tristi de la fredda crosta 110 gridò a noi: «O anime crudeli 111 tanto che data v’è l’ultima posta,
112 levatemi dal viso i duri veli, 113 sì ch’ïo sfoghi ’l duol che ’l cor m’impregna, 114 un poco, pria che ’l pianto si raggeli».
query.result:
**English:**
109 And one of the wretches from the cold crust 110 cried out to us: “O souls so cruel 111 that the final resting place has been given to you,
112 lift the hard veils from my face, 113 so that I may vent the grief that fills my heart, 114 for a little while, before my weeping freezes”.
**Cornish:**
109 Ha unn a'n drus a'n eryr yen skorra 110 a leveris dhe'n: “O eneves kruele 111 byttegyns le mayth an nessa sedhas dhiso,
112 kodhyth an gorhelli kalessa a'm fas, 113 henna dhe wul dhe dowr a wra'm kolon, 114 rag skon, kyns na wra'n an gwela ow kodha”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
115 Per ch’io a lui: «Se vuo’ ch’i’ ti sovvegna, 116 dimmi chi se’, e s’io non ti disbrigo, 117 al fondo de la ghiaccia ir mi convegna».
query.result:
**English:**
115 So I said to him: “If you want me to remember you, 116 tell me who you are, and if I do not free you, 117 may I be forced to go to the bottom of the ice”.
**Cornish:**
115 Rag henna dhe'm: “Mas te a vynna dhe'm kovsowle, 116 lever dhiso pyw os, ha mas nag dhe wul dhe dhiso, 117 dhe'n nessa a'n eryr dhe wra dhe'm dhe vos”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Rispuose adunque: «I’ son frate Alberigo; 119 i’ son quel da le frutta del mal orto, 120 che qui riprendo dattero per figo».
query.result:
**English:**
118 He answered then: “I am Brother Alberigo; 119 I am the one from the fruits of the evil orchard, 120 who here takes dates for figs”.
**Cornish:**
118 Ha henna a leveris: “My a'n Frer Alberigo; 119 my a'n unn a'n frooth a'n eryr drwg, 120 a wra dhe'm dhe vos dhe'n le mayth dates rag figys”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
121 «Oh», diss’ io lui, «or se’ tu ancor morto?». 122 Ed elli a me: «Come ’l mio corpo stea 123 nel mondo sù, nulla scïenza porto.
query.result:
**English:**
121 “Oh,” I said to him, “are you dead already?”. 122 And he to me: “How my body fared 123 in the world above, I have no knowledge.
**Cornish:**
121 “O,” leveris dhe'm, “os ow marow byth?”. 122 Ha henna dhe'm: “Kepar ha'm korf o stea 123 yn-nans an bys, vyth skians nag eus owm”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
124 Cotal vantaggio ha questa Tolomea, 125 che spesse volte l’anima ci cade 126 innanzi ch’Atropòs mossa le dea.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Such advantage has this Ptolomea, 125 that often the soul falls here 126 before Atropos gives it the signal.
**Cornish:**
124 An vantaji ma 'vel a'n Ptolomea, 125 rag liesow le mayth an enef a wra dhe vos 126 kyns na wra Atropos an arwodh dhe dhiso.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 E perché tu più volentier mi rade 128 le ’nvetrïate lagrime dal volto, 129 sappie che, tosto che l’anima trade
130 come fec’ ïo, il corpo suo l’è tolto 131 da un demonio, che poscia il governa 132 mentre che ’l tempo suo tutto sia vòlto.
query.result:
**English:**
127 And so that you more willingly scrape off 128 the frozen tears from my face, 129 know that, as soon as the soul betrays
130 its body as I did, a demon takes it 131 and then controls it 132 until its allotted time has fully run its course.
**Cornish:**
127 Ha rag dhe vos dhe wra dhe vynna moy radya 128 an dowr yen skorra a'm fas, 129 gowghvos, pan wrus an enef an drega
130 kepar ha wrussa vy, an korf a wra dhe vos 131 gans demon, a wra dhe wosa henna 132 bys na wra an amser a wra dhe vos ow kul.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Ella ruina in sì fatta cisterna; 134 e forse pare ancor lo corpo suso 135 de l’ombra che di qua dietro mi verna.
query.result:
**English:**
133 She fell into such a cistern; 134 and perhaps her body still appears above 135 from the shadow that screens me from behind.
**Cornish:**
133 Hi a ruw yn onan cisterna leun; 134 ha mos ow kul ow korf a-ugh 135 a'gan owr owth a'm verna.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 Tu ’l dei saper, se tu vien pur mo giuso: 137 elli è ser Branca Doria, e son più anni 138 poscia passati ch’el fu sì racchiuso».
query.result:
**English:**
136 You should know this, if you have indeed come down here: 137 he is Ser Branca Doria, and it has been more years 138 since he was shut in here than I can count.
**Cornish:**
136 Dyskis ow, pub vyth owth a dheuth mo isel: 137 Hi yw Ser Branca Doria, ha moy blydhennow 138 ow tremensys owth a veu kudhys leun.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
139 «Io credo», diss’ io lui, «che tu m’inganni; 140 ché Branca Doria non morì unquanche, 141 e mangia e bee e dorme e veste panni».
query.result:
**English:**
139 “I believe,” I said to him, “that you are deceiving me; 140 for Branca Doria never died, 141 and he eats and drinks and sleeps and wears clothes.”
**Cornish:**
139 “Kredys vy,” me a leveris, “owth owth ow m’enganna; 140 rag Branca Doria nyns yw marow byth, 141 ha’n ev, ha’n yv, ha’n kosk, ha’n gwisk pannow.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
142 «Nel fosso sù», diss’ el, «de’ Malebranche, 143 là dove bolle la tenace pece, 144 non era ancora giunto Michel Zanche,
145 che questi lasciò il diavolo in sua vece 146 nel corpo suo, ed un suo prossimano 147 che ’l tradimento insieme con lui fece.
query.result:
**English:**
142 “In the ditch above,” he said, “of the Malebranche, 143 where the sticky pitch boils, 144 Michele Zanche had not yet arrived,
145 when this one left the devil in his place 146 in his body, and one of his close companions 147 who committed the treachery together with him.
**Cornish:**
142 “Y’n fos owth ugh,” leveris, “a’gan Malebranche, 143 le mayth ow pech tenacyus ow bolla, 144 nyns o veu junys Michel Zanche,
145 pan wrug an onan ma an diawl y’n le, 146 y’n korf, ha unan a’y gomprenow 147 a wrug an treson gans.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
151 Ahi Genovesi, uomini diversi 152 d’ogne costume e pien d’ogne magagna, 153 perché non siete voi del mondo spersi?
154 Ché col peggiore spirto di Romagna 155 trovai di voi un tal, che per sua opra 156 in anima in Cocito già si bagna,
157 e in corpo par vivo ancor di sopra.
query.result:
**English:**
151 Ah, Genoese, men different 152 from every custom and full of every evil, 153 why are you not scattered from the world?
154 For with the worst spirit of Romagna 155 I found one of you, such that for his deeds 156 his soul is already bathing in Cocytus,
157 and in body he still seems alive above.
**Cornish:**
151 Ah, Genovesi, tusow dyffrans 152 a bub kostom ha leun a bub drok, 153 peraga’th nyns ywthwi spersi a’n bys?
154 Rag gans an speris gwethha a’n Romanha 155 kavos unan a’thwi, le mayth y ober 156 y’n eneval y’n Cocito hedhyw ow kolla,
157 ha y’n korf owth owth a wel byw a-ugh.
